title.value: Global Rewards in Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Mobility on Demand Systems
title.justification: This is the title provided at the beginning of the research paper. It clearly states the primary focus of the research work.
title.quote: Global Rewards in Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Mobility on Demand Systems

extractions.description: The paper proposes a novel global-rewards-based multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MADRL) algorithm for vehicle dispatching in autonomous mobility on demand (AMoD) systems. This algorithm assigns rewards to agents using a counterfactual baseline to align the agents' goals with the overall system profit, thereby resolving conflicts between individual agent objectives and the global objective of the operator. The paper demonstrates significant improvements in performance over state-of-the-art MADRL algorithms that use local rewards, utilizing real-world data in various settings. Additionally, the paper provides a structural analysis highlighting benefits in vehicle balancing and demand forecasting from using global rewards.

type.justification: The study utilizes real-world data to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm and provides quantitative performance comparisons against the current state-of-the-art, making it an empirical study.
type.quote: Our algorithm shows statistically significant improvements across various settings on real-world data compared to state-of-the-art MADRL algorithms with local rewards.

name.justification: The research primarily focuses on developing a reinforcement learning algorithm for vehicle dispatching in AMoD systems, integrating global rewards into a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning framework.
name.quote: Recent approaches use multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MADRL) to realize scalable yet performant algorithms, but train agents based on local rewards, which distorts the reward signal with respect to the system-wide profit, leading to lower performance.

name.justification: The research application is in the domain of autonomous mobility on demand systems, specifically focusing on vehicle dispatching algorithms.
name.quote: We study vehicle dispatching in autonomous mobility on demand (AMoD) systems, where a central operator assigns vehicles to customer requests or rejects these with the aim of maximizing its total profit.

name.justification: The research extends to multi-agent systems as it develops a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning approach for the AMoD problem.
name.quote: Our algorithm combines the benefits of low learning variance and sample efficiency of SAC with the benefits of credit assignment via a counterfactual baseline.

name.justification: The Local-Rewards Algorithm (LRA) is mentioned as the base state-of-the-art algorithm for comparison.
name.quote: In this work, we improve upon the state-of-the-art local-rewards algorithm (LRA) of Enders et al. (2023)

is_contributed.justification: This model is used as a benchmark for comparison and is not developed within this paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this work, we improve upon the state-of-the-art local-rewards algorithm (LRA) of Enders et al. (2023)

is_executed.justification: The LRA model is executed and compared against the newly proposed algorithms in the study.
is_executed.quote: Our algorithm outperforms LRA by up to 2% on average across test dates and up to 6% on individual dates, which is a substantial performance improvement in AMoD.

is_compared.justification: The LRA model is used for performance comparison with the proposed global-rewards-based algorithm.
is_compared.quote: Our algorithm shows statistically significant improvements across various settings on real-world data compared to state-of-the-art MADRL algorithms with local rewards.

referenced_paper_title.value: Hybrid Multi-agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Mobility on Demand Systems
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Local-Rewards Algorithm (LRA) is based on the work of Enders et al. (2023), which is referenced in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In this work, we improve upon the state-of-the-art local-rewards algorithm (LRA) of Enders et al. (2023)

name.justification: The dataset used consists of yellow taxi trip records from 2015, covering multiple time intervals in Manhattan.
name.quote: Our data consists of yellow taxi trip records from 2015, excluding weekends and holidays.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset used in the research is cited as NYC TLC (2015), providing trip record data for the experiments conducted.
referenced_paper_title.quote: NYC TLC. Trip Record Data. Online, 2015. URL htps://www.nyc.gov/site/tlc/about/tlc-trip-record-data.page.

name.justification: PyTorch is mentioned as a deep learning framework used in the implementation of the models.
name.quote: We train the models using the PyTorch framework.

referenced_paper_title.value: PyTorch: An Imperative Style, High-Performance Deep Learning Library
referenced_paper_title.justification: The PyTorch library is cited in the context of its use for training the models in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: PyTorch was used for implementing and training the models.
